item.title: How to get people to choose your product
item.content:encoded: Anything you build has to compete for attention with the other available options. If someone can just as easily buy a similar product from a more trusted brand for the same price, why would they choose you? To compete with established brands, you’ll need to figure out how to differentiate yourself in meaningful ways.

item.title: The secret is to sell what people are already searching for
item.content:encoded: Most purchases start with a search. While some purchases are impulse-driven (like seeing something cool on Instagram and buying right away), most sales come from intent-based searches.

item.title: is twitter done?
item.content:encoded: Elon took possession of Twitter on October 27. Since then, lots has happened. Many are wondering: is this going to kill Twitter?

item.title: How to use Mastodon: a beginner's guide
item.content:encoded: I've been trying out Mastodon. Overall, I'm digging it. People bill it as a Twitter alternative. While there are some similarities, it's definitely its own thing.

item.title: musk twitter quitter, bitter?
item.content:encoded: I've been a big Twitter user since 2008. In nearly 14 years on the platform, Twitter's had a net-positive effect on my life. But now with Elon’s takeover, Twitter is in the hands of a man whose behavior I find reprehensible.

item.title: The potential dark side of AI and GPT-3 writing tools
item.content:encoded: What happens when people start going to the AI for answers instead of Google search and Wikipedia? How does the AI decide what to suggest? What are the knock-on effects of these suggestions?

item.title: The ethics of AI-driven feeds
item.content:encoded: What if we had a personal AI that could write the perfect thing just for us? A thoughtful AI, trained to challenge the human mind in healthy ways, could potentially improve human society. But it could also optimized to fulfill every unhealthy human desire and habit.

item.title: AI-driven content is a nightmare
item.content:encoded: Giving people a never-ending stream of content designed to keep them on a centralized platform longer where the algorithm is controlled by some megacorp (and its shareholders) isn’t my idea of a great future. It’s fucking dystopian.

item.title: Older founders do this better
item.content:encoded: There's a popular narrative in Silicon Valley that you have to be in your 20s to build a successful startup. But founders in their 40s, 50s, 60s are more likely to be successful.

item.title: What's wrong with Elon?

item.title: What makes you click on a YouTube video?
item.content:encoded: As an indie business, creating videos seems to be a good search optimization strategy. We're trying to rank for terms like "how to start a podcast," and well-made video can show up in search results (both on Google and YouTube).

item.title: Working harder doesn't make you more successful

item.title: It might never go away
item.content:encoded: When you click "publish" thousands of copies are generated and sent to individual inboxes. Once you've sent an email, people can keep a copy of it in their archive, forever. You can't take it back.
